sen.j: 町人（ちょうにん、まちにん）とは、江戸時代に都市に居住していた職人、商人のこと。
sen.e: Chonin (or machinin) is a term referring to craftsmen and merchants who lived in the cities during the Edo Period.
Chonin (or machinin) is a term referring to craftsmen and merchants who lived in the urban area during the Edo period.
Chonin (or machinin) is a term referring to craftsmen and merchants who lived in the urban area during the Edo period.

sen.j: 江戸時代前期に、身分制度（士農工商）が成立し、末端の工商の部分にあてられた。
sen.e: With the class system (warrior, farmer, craftsman and merchant classes) established in the first half of the Edo Period, the two lowest classes came under this category.
With the class system (warrior, farmer, craftsman and merchant classes) established in the early Edo period, Chonin was ranked the two lowest classes in the category.
sen.cmt: ・修正in the first half of the Edo Period→in the early Edo periodthe two lowest classes came under this category.→Chonin was ranked the two lowest classes in the category.
sen.e: With the class system (warrior, farmer, craftsman and merchant classes) established in the early Edo period, Chonin was ranked the two lowest classes in the category.

sen.j: このことにより職業的に農業との分離が促進され、より専門性が高まった。
sen.e: This led to the steady separation of these occupations away from farming and greater specialization.
This encouraged categorical separation of these occupations away from farming and led them greater specialization.
sen.cmt: ・修正led→encouragedthe steady separation→categorical separationand greater specialization.→and led them greater specialization.
sen.e: This encouraged categorical separation of these occupations away from farming and led them greater specialization.

sen.j: 身分的には下層社会であったが、優れた技術力と豊富な資金量は武士を圧倒する面もみせ、独自の都市文化（町人文化）の形成発展に寄与した。
sen.e: In social status, they were among the lowly but showed superiority over the samurai class at time with their outstanding technological skills and abundant financial resources, contributing to the development of distinctive urban cultures (plebian cultures).

In the social status, they ranked at lower position but showed superiority over the samurai class at times with their outstanding craftsmanship and abundant financial resources, which contributed to the development of distinctive urban cultures (Chonin culture [townsmen culture].)
sen.cmt: ・修正In social status→In the social status they were among the lowly→they ranked at lower positionat time→at timestechnological skills→craftsmanship, contributing→, which contributed(plebian cultures).→(Chonin culture [townsmen culture].)
sen.e: In the social status, they ranked at lower position but showed superiority over the samurai class at times with their outstanding craftsmanship and abundant financial resources, which contributed to the development of distinctive urban cultures (Chonin culture [townsmen culture].)

sen.j: しかしながら、単なる商工身分の者全般を町人と呼ぶわけではなく、特にブルジョワ階級である旦那衆のことを指し、家屋敷を所有する者のことを言う。
sen.e: It must be noted that the term is not used for all working in commerce and industry but refer to the owners and the masters who made up the bourgeoisie and possessed their own estates.

It must be noted that the term was not used for all the people classified in artisans and merchants classes but referred to the owners and the masters who made up the bourgeoisie and possessed their own estates.
sen.cmt: ・修正is→wasrefer→referredall working in commerce and industry→all the people classified in artisans and merchants class
sen.e: It must be noted that the term was not used for all the people classified in artisans and merchants classes but referred to the owners and the masters who made up the bourgeoisie and possessed their own estates.

sen.j: また町政や公事にも参加し、町年寄を選ぶ選挙権や被選挙権を持つなど、社会的身分や公的権利・義務を持つ者である。
sen.e: They were also participants in local politics and public events and held social status, as well as public rights and obligations, such as casting votes when selecting town elders.

They participated in local politics and public events, also held social status, as well as public rights and obligations, which entitled them voting right and eligibility for machi-doshiyori (ward head) selection.
sen.cmt: ・修正were also participants→participated, such as casting votes when selecting town elders.→, which entitled them voting right and eligibility for machi-doshiyori (ward head) selection.
sen.e: They participated in local politics and public events, also held social status, as well as public rights and obligations, which entitled them voting right and eligibility for machi-doshiyori (ward head) selection.

sen.j: また町人としての社会的役割のひとつに賃貸しの長屋を持ちわずかな店賃で店子に貸す慣習があった。
sen.e: One social function of the townspeople was to manage the nagaya, rented out to people for a small fee (tanachin).
One social function of Chonin was to rent nagaya (a row house) to tanako (tenant) for a small tanachin (rent.)
sen.cmt: ・修正the townspeople was to manage the nagaya, rented out to people for a small fee (tanachin). →Chonin was to rent nagaya (a row house) to tanako (tenant) for a small tanachin (rent.)
sen.e: One social function of Chonin was to rent nagaya (a row house) to tanako (tenant) for a small tanachin (rent.)

sen.j: そして大家を雇い店子からの家賃の取立てや諸事の面倒など長屋の管理運営を任せ、その対価として店賃の免除などの優遇をした。
sen.e: They hired people as to serve as managers in charge of managing the nagaya, collecting rent and mediating in problems, and paid them in return with rent-free residence, etc.

They hired oya (landlord) who was committed administration of nagaya including management service such as collecting rent and mediating in problems, in consideration of the task, oya received benefits such as exemption of rent and so on.
sen.cmt: ・変更少し読みずらかったので変更を加えました。
sen.e: They hired oya (landlord) who was committed administration of nagaya including management service such as collecting rent and mediating in problems, in consideration of the task, oya received benefits such as exemption of rent and so on.

sen.j: ちなみに落語などに出てくる八公・熊公などは借家人であるため厳密に言えば町人にはあたらない。
sen.e: As a side note to this, characters that appear in rakugo tales such as Hachiko and Kumako, are nagaya tenants and are not townspeople in the strict sense.
As a side note to this, Hachiko and Kumako, famous characters that appear in rakugo tales, are nagaya tenants, not townspeople in the strict sense.
